; ;Summary.   ; ;

;An entirely new “management paradigm” for data is needed. As used here, a “management paradigm” embodies a common language, a holistic vision of the ways data should contribute, a clearly defined organizational structure showing how data integrates across the organization, along with clear roles and responsibilities for all involved. Eventually, it needs to incorporate corporate culture, relationships with universities and vendors, policy, and anything else that advances, or holds back the effective use of data. The new paradigm employs a more pervasive and integrated approach to using data, analytics, and AI in the business.

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;Leer en español;
; ;Ler em português;
;

;If the past few decades have confirmed anything, it is the power of data, broadly defined to include activity involving small data, big data, statistics, analytics, and artificial intelligence by employees at every level of sophistication, to help companies improve their performance, in many ways. On one end of the spectrum, artificial intelligence (AI), especially generative AI, promises to transform business and so garners the most excitement. On the other end, ;basic analyses using small amounts of data; are stunningly effective in helping companies make better decisions, control and improve business processes, better understand customers, and enhance products and services. Read the popular press and you might conclude that data, analytics, and AI are taking over the world.

;

;However, other than for digital natives, a deeper look reveals a far bleaker reality. Despite massive investment, great tools, and plenty of qualified data analysts and scientists, progress in ;AI is slow, expensive, and uncertain;. Most data science models are not actually ;deployed into production;, yielding no actual economic value. The ;tenure; of most Chief Data and Analytics Officers is so short it is unrealistic to expect them to get much done. “Regular people,” those without data in their titles, don't know what is expected of them and, despite claims to the contrary, fear that analytics and AI will change, even eliminate, their jobs. Most companies eschew small data, robbing themselves of easier-to-obtain business benefits and the chance to build the organizational muscle needed to attack more difficult problems.

;

;It is all too easy to call for “data-driven cultures,” but actually defining and building such cultures is far beyond the ken of most data professionals. ;Survey data; suggests that relatively few companies actually have data-driven cultures. Finally, current levels of data quality simply do not support data analysis or science at scale.

;

;It's Time for Fresh Thinking

;

;Digging still deeper, it is easy to understand the root causes of these disappointing realities:  Companies have essentially “bolted data onto” their organization charts, naming Chief Data and Analytics Officers, establishing Centers of Excellence, and hiring highly-educated data scientists, then turning them loose with few guidelines and little supervision. That some succeed is a testament to the tenacity of the few, who've overcome organizational hurdles against long odds. Data leaders are not blind to the issues. They've hired data wranglers and engineers to help overcome bad data and ;product managers; to help better connect to the business. Still, it all feels like an elaborate (and largely futile) game of “whack-a-mole.”  Continuing down the current path is ill-fated.

;

;Rather, we suggest that an entirely new “management paradigm” for data is needed. As used here, a “management paradigm” embodies a common language, a holistic vision of the ways data should contribute, a clearly defined organizational structure showing how data integrates across the organization, along with clear roles and responsibilities for all involved. Eventually, it needs to incorporate corporate culture, relationships with universities and vendors, policy, and anything else that advances, or holds back the effective use of data. The new paradigm employs a more pervasive and integrated approach to using data, analytics, and AI in the business.

;

;But what steps should companies take now to work towards a new paradigm? How should they think about fully integrating data into their business strategies? What targets should they aim for, and what should they do initially? This article builds on our research into hundreds of companies and government agencies wrestling with these questions, work with a couple of dozen of them, and our experience with other relevant paradigms to propose three interconnected steps companies should take now.

;

;Use a “Digital Native” as a Guiding Light

;

;First of all, we propose Google as a candidate “North Star.” After all, data is so much a part of the mainstream at Google that it doesn't even have a Chief Data or Analytics Officer, though it does have a ;Chief Decision Officer;, whose primary mission is spreading the good word about data-driven decisions. Google pioneered ;people analytics; and is one of few whose ;legal operations make extensive use of analytics;. Analytics and AI are embedded into most of the company's products and services, and the company's CEO declared it would be “AI first” back in 2016. It pioneered many of the approaches used in today's generative AI systems.

;

;Other digital native firms, like Meta/Facebook and Amazon, have similarly pervasive usage of analytics and AI, and our research and consulting in these firms suggests that, unlike in more traditional companies, data leaders don't have to spend a lot of time evangelizing about the importance of these tools; it is simply taken for granted and viewed as an essential element of the culture.

;

;A few legacy businesses are adopting similar approaches, but not enough. At DBS Bank, for example, the largest bank in Southeast Asia, ;CEO Piyush Gupta argues; that the bank's future competitors are not traditional banks, but rather digital native firms like Alibaba, Tencent, and Ant Financial. To compete with those companies, he believes, DBS must collect, manage, and analyze data as well or better than they do. The bank has hired or trained over a thousand data scientists and engineers, developed its own AI applications, adopted a broad AI literacy program, and encouraged development of AI use cases across all business functions and units.

;

;Learn from Other Mainstream Business Functions

;

;Secondly, for those who may find the idea of following Google's or DBS's examples too steep a hill to climb right now, a nearer-term role model found in virtually every organization is the finance organization. Even non-profits and governmental agencies have finance groups. In our collective experience, we feel that finance, perhaps more than any other function, has achieved the goal of going mainstream.

;

;Going mainstream is the antithesis of being a silo; it means being fully integrated with all aspects of the organization. Consider the attributes of most finance organizations:

;
    ;
  • ;The finance organization is clearly seen as strategic, with most Boards of Directors having their own finance committees, and expecting financial reports at every meeting.
    • ;
  • ;The CFO is typically in the “inner circle” of the CEO, and involved in virtually all major decisions.
    • ;
  • ;The tenure of CFO's tends to be much longer than of Chief Data Officers, which as noted above, tends to be quite short. Further, rapid turnover of CFO's sends a warning signal to Wall Street.
    • ;
  • ;Finance employees are integrated into virtually every facility, operating plant, division, and so on, and have at least a dotted line into corporate finance.
    • ;
  • ;Virtually every manager knows how to conduct basic financial tasks, including preparing a budget, computing ROI, and so forth. Most managers spend a lot of time on financial work.
    • ;
  • ;Finance makes clear what is expected, provides the tools and processes it expects people to follow, and monitors compliance. Following financial procedures is not optional.
    • ;
  • ;Finance goes to enormous lengths to make sure the data it uses, and provides, is of extremely high-quality.
    • ;
;

;The above list starts with viewing finance as strategic. This would be a significant step forward in taking data mainstream. If learning from and monetizing data are viewed as strategic opportunities, then the organization should consider how to implement each of these bullet points for data.

;

;Finally, Get Everyone Involved

;

;Lastly, we have enormous sympathy for senior managers. While data analysis has been around for a long time, the technologies themselves are daunting and the hype makes it appear that implementing them is far easier than it actually is. Exacerbating this, the urgency of doing so appears to grow exponentially. It is easy for non-technical employees to get lost in the shuffle. Yet as much as trusted data and dogged implementation of the technology, they are essential! Consider that even elite data scientists cannot truly define a business problem, understand the data, nor deploy a model into a business process without their help. Nor can you make the needed improvements to data.

;

;Admittedly, we are bullish on data over the long-term. We see the potential to decrease the drudgery in billions of jobs, augment others, and create whole new, high-paying jobs (we are just as aware of the downside risks). At the same time, we think people are smart to be fearful — after all, drudge jobs put food on the table for billions of people world-wide. Obviously, it would be best if senior leaders could eliminate such fears, but we think that unlikely for most companies. Still, we advise senior leaders to acknowledge the fear, just as senior leaders who don't get serious about data very soon should be doubly fearful.

;

;Instead, we advise senior leaders to recruit as many regular people involved as possible into their data effort. Practically everyone can bring ;small data and basic analytics to improve their team's performance;. Such efforts build skill and confidence and collectively can make a real difference. And for many companies, they appear to be pre-requisite for taking on bigger data and ;more advanced techniques;. Finally, many regular people find small data empowering and so are more than happy to join the fun.

;

;Urgency Is in Order

;

;Companies can, of course, manage themselves however they please; though of course they should strive to do so in ways that make it easier to conduct its most important work. After all, even the smallest company is a complicated place. One implication is that some things get more and better attention than others. Up until 10 years ago, the relative lack of attention around data made sense — it simply was not in the mainstream, nor did it need to be. This makes considerably less sense today. Just hiring chief data and analytics officers is no longer enough. Companies must make some significant changes to the management paradigms for data and their most senior leaders must lead the charge.
